fields: What is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)?

A severe mucocutaneous blistering disease, with >30% of body surface area involvement.

NOTES
A more severe version of Stevens Johnson syndrome (SJS).
Most commonly caused by drugs e.g. allopurinol, sulfonamide antibiotics.
SJS = Stevens Johnson Syndrome.
TEN = toxic epidermal necrolysis.

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of generalised pruritus? (no rash)

Sort by mechanism

1. Malignancy e.g. Hodgkin lymphoma, PRV.
2. Renal failure (uraemia).
3. Cholestasis.
4. Hyperthyroidism.
5. Drugs e.g. opiates.

NOTES
PRV = polycythaemia rubra vera.

UPDATED 2020
What is Stevens Johnson Syndrome (SJS)?

A severe mucocutaneous blistering disease, with <10% of body surface area involvement.



NOTES
A less severe version of toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN).
The most common cause is medications e.g. sulfonamide antibiotics.

UPDATED 2020
What are the complications of SJS/TEN?

Sort by mechanism

1. Volume loss e.g. shock, AKI.
2. Electrolyte derangement.
3. Infection e.g. sepsis, pneumonia.
4. Hypothermia.

NOTES
SJS = Stevens Johnson Syndrome.
TEN = toxic epidermal necrolysis.
AKI = acute kidney injury.

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for SJS/TEN?

1. Resus
A+B - consider airway support and O2.
C - IV fluids, catheter, monitor input/output.
Consider referral to ICU or burns unit.

2. Supportive care e.g. wound care, fluids and nutrition, prevent hypothermia, prevent infections.

UPDATED 2020
What is erythroderma?

Diffuse erythema and scaling, with ≥90% of body surface area involvement.



NOTES
Also called 'exfoliative dermatitis'.
Causes include psoriasis, atopic dermatitis, drug reactions, and cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

UPDATED 2020
What are the complications of erythroderma?

Sort by mechanism

1. Volume loss e.g. shock, AKI.
2. Electrolyte derangement.
3. Infection e.g. sepsis, pneumonia.
4. Hypothermia.

NOTES
Systemic complications are relatively uncommon.
AKI = acute kidney injury.

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for erythroderma?

1. Resus
A+B - consider airway support and O2.
C - consider IV fluids.
Consider referral to ICU or burns unit.

2. Supportive care e.g. fluids and nutrition, prevent hypothermia, prevent infections.

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of erythroderma?

Sort by prevalence

1. Inflammatory skin disease e.g. psoriasis, atopic dermatitis.
2. Drug reaction e.g. penicillin, sulfonamides.
3. Cutaneous T cell lymphoma.

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of SJS/TEN?

Sort by prevalence

1. Drugs e.g. allopurinol, carbamazepine, sulfonamide antibiotics.
2. Infection e.g. mycoplasma pneumoniae, CMV.
3. Other e.g. vaccinations.

NOTES
Patients with HIV infection have increased risk of SJS/TEN.
SJS = Stevens Johnson Syndrome.
TEN = toxic epidermal necrolysis.
CMV = cytomegalovirus.

UPDATED 2020
What is cellulitis?

Bacterial infection of the deep dermis and subcutaneous fat.

NOTES
Microbiology: majority of cases are caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci, a minority by Staphylococcus aureus.

Right leg cellulitis

UPDATED 2020
What is erysipelas?

Bacterial infection of the upper dermis and superficial lymphatics.

NOTES
Lesion is raised above the surrounding skin, and has a clear line of demarcation.
Microbiology: large majority of cases are caused by beta-haemolytic Streptococci.

Erysipelas

UPDATED 2020
What is necrotising fasciitis?

A destructive bacterial infection of the muscle fascia and subcutaneous fat.

NOTES


Initially, overlying tissue can appear unaffected (pain is out of proportion to exam findings).
Microbiology: type 1 (mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection), type 2 (group A Streptococci) and type 3 (gas gangrene, due to clostridium)

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of necrotising fasciitis?

History
Poorly-defined area of redness, severe pain.

Exam
Obs: fever, tachycardia.
Inspection: poorly-defined area of redness and swelling.
Palpation: exquisitely tender, subcut tissue may be firm and indurated.

NOTES
Clinical course if untreated: over a few days, skin changes from red-purple to blue-grey, then breaks down to form bullae with frank cutaneous gangrene.

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for necrotising fasciitis?

1. Resus
A+B - consider airway support and O2.
C - IV fluids, catheter, monitor input/output.
NBM.

2. Surgery (urgent exploration and debridement, with broad spectrum antibiotics)

UPDATED 2020
What is impetigo?

A type of bacterial infection of the epidermis (usually Staphyloccocus aureus).

NOTES
Impetigo is most common in children (highly contagious).
Primary = previously normal skin.
Secondary = impetigo at site of skin lesion e.g. eczema.
Clinical variants include non-bullous, bullous, and ecthyma.

Impetigo

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for impetigo?

1. Conservative e.g. keep child home from school.

2. Meds
Topical e.g. mupirocin, fusidic acid.
Oral e.g. dicloxacillin.

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for cellulitis?

1. Resus
A+B - consider airway support and O2.
C - consider IV fluids.

2. Elevation of affected area.

3. Meds e.g. flucloxacillin IV.

UPDATED 2020
What is erythrasma?

A type of bacterial infection of the epidermis (C. minutissimum).

NOTES
Lesions are macerated, scaly plaques between the toes or in intertriginous areas.
Corynebacterium minutissimum = a Gram positive, non spore-forming bacillus.
Diagnosis is made by observing coral-red fluorescence under Wood's lamp.

Axillary erythrasma

Fluorescence under Wood's light

UPDATED 2020
What is the treatment for erythrasma?

1. Meds
Topical e.g. fusidic acid, clindamycin, imidazole antifungals.
Oral e.g. clarithromycin.

UPDATED 2020
What is a furuncle?

Bacterial infection of a hair follicle, with formation of an abscess in the dermis.

NOTES
Also called a 'boil'.
Microbiology: large majority of cases are caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

Furuncle (boil)

UPDATED 2020
What is a carbuncle?

Bacterial infection of hair follicles, with abscess formation in the dermis and purulent discharge from multiple follicles.

NOTES
Microbiology: large majority of cases are caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
Treament: incision and drainage, antibiotics.

Carbuncle

UPDATED 2020
What is folliculitis?

Superficial bacterial infection of the hair follicles.

NOTES
Microbiology: large majority of cases are caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
Pseudomonas is an important pathogen in the setting of inadequately chlorinated hot tubs and swimming pools.

Folliculitis

UPDATED 2020
What are common warts?

Nodular skin lesions, caused by HPV.

NOTES
Treatment: salicylic acid or liquid nitrogen.
HPV = human papilloma virus.

Common warts.

UPDATED 2020
What are plantar warts?

Inwardly growing lesions on the sole of the foot, due to HPV.

NOTES
Also called verrucas.
Mosaic warts = plaques of coalescing plantar warts.
Treatment: salicylic acid or liquid nitrogen.
HPV = human papilloma virus.

Plantar warts

UPDATED 2020
What is a dermatophyte infection?

A fungal infection of the epidermis.

NOTES
Clinical variants include tinea -capitis, -pedis, -cruris, and -corporis.
Diagnosis: clinical features, microscopy and culture of skin scrapings.
Treatment: topical antifungal cream (oral antifungal in severe disease).

Tinea capitis

Tinea pedis (athlete's foot)

Tinea cruris (jock's itch)

 UPDATED 2020
What is scabies?

Skin infestation with a mite



NOTES
Scabies causes an intensely itchy rash with a characteristic distribution.
Microbiology: caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei.
What are the clinical features of scabies?

History
Severe itching, worse at night and in warm conditions.
Common sites include the finger webs and flexor aspect of the wrist.

Exam
Inspection: lesion (small erythematous papule), burrow (thin greyish line 2-15mm long), excoriations, secondary infections.

NOTES
Transmission is by person-to-person contact.

Scabies

Crusted scabies (seen in immunodeficiency)

UPDATED 2020
Which investigations may be useful in suspected scabies?

Sort by type

1. Dermoscopy.
2. Microscopy (skin scraping or adhesive tape test).

UPDATED 2020
What is psoriasis?

A chronic inflammatory skin disorder, most commonly characterised by erythematous plaques with silver scale.

NOTES

Guttate Psoriasis             Plaque Psoriasis                        Nail Psoriasis 
Clinical variants include guttate, pustular, erythrodermic, inverse, and nail psoriasis.
A minority of patients have associated psoriatic arthritis.
UPDATED 2020
What is chronic plaque psoriasis?

The most common clinical variant of psoriasis

NOTES
Sites: usually symmetrical involvement of scalp, extensor elbows, knees, back.
Lesions: raised, sharply defined plaques with silvery scale (chronic).

Chronic plaque psoriasis

UPDATED 2020
What is the Koebner phenomenon?

Development of skin disease at sites of skin trauma.

NOTES
Diseases include psoriasis, vitiligo, and lichen planus.

UPDATED 2020
What is guttate psoriasis?

An uncommon clinical variant of psoriasis

NOTES
Characterised by the abrupt appearance of many small psoriatic plaques and papules on the trunk and proximal extremities.
Typical patient is a young adult with recent Streptococcal pharyngitis.
Guttate = drop-like.

Guttate psoriasis

UPDATE 2020
What is generalised pustular psoriasis?

An uncommon clinical variant of psoriasis

NOTES
Generalised pustular psoriasis (von Zumbusch type) = acute widespread erythema, scaling, and sheets of superficial pustules (may be life-threatening).

Generalised pustular psoriasis

UPDATED 2020
What is inverse psoriasis?

An uncommon clinical variant of psoriasis

NOTES
Also called 'flexural psoriasis'.
Characterised by involvement of the intertriginous areas (skin folds).
Often there is no visible scaling, often misdiagnosed as fungal or bacterial infection.


 UPDATED 2020
Where are the 'intertriginous areas'?

The body folds e.g. inguinal, intergluteal, axillary, and submammary skin.

NOTES
Also called the 'flexural distribution'.

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'acral'?

Describes lesions in distal portions of the limbs (hands, feet) and head (ears, nose).


Acral Lentiginous Melanoma 
UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'annular'?

Describes lesions grouped in a circle. 


Annular erythema 
UPDATED 2020
Where are the apocrine glands found?

In the arpits and groin.

NOTES
These sweat glands become active after puberty.

UPDATED 2020
What is a bulla?

A blister, >1cm across.

UPDATED 2020
What is 'crusting'?

When plasma exudes through eroded epidermis and dries on the skin.

UPDATED 2020
What is a dermatosis?

A skin disease.

UPDATED 2020
What is 'desquamation'?

Peeling skin.

UPDATED 2020
What are ecchymoses?

Purpura >1cm across

NOTES
Also called bruises.

Ecchymoses

UPDATED 2020
What is 'exfoliation'?

Peeling skin.

UPDATED 2020
What is a fissure?

A thin crack within the epidermis, due to excessive dryness.

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'fungating'?

Describes a tumour erupting like a fungus



UPDATED 2020
What is 'lichenification'?

Thickened skin with increased skin markings and lichenoid scale, caused by chronic rubbing.

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'maceration'?

Moist, peeling skin

UPDATED 2020
What is a macule?

A smooth area of colour change, <1cm across

UPDATED 2020
What is a patch?

A smooth area of colour change, >1cm across

UPDATED 2020
What is a nodule?

A palpable skin lesion, >1cm across

UPDATED 2020
What is a papule?

A palpable skin lesion, <1cm across

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'nummular'?

Describes a round (coin shaped) lesion


Exudative Nummular Dermatitis 
UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'pedunculated'?

Decribes a lesion with a stalk (a peduncle)

UPDATED 2020
What are petechiae?

Purpura <1cm across

NOTES

Petechiae

UPDATED 2020
What are purpura?

Non-blanching skin lesions, due to bleeding from superficial blood vessels.

NOTES
Petechiae = purpura <1cm.
Ecchymoses = purpura >1cm.

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'pityriasis'?

Bran-like powdery scale

UPDATED 2020
What is a plaque?

A palpable flat lesion

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'scaling'?

An increase in dead cells on the skin

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'serpiginous'?

Describes a lesion in the shape of a snake


UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'sessile'?

Describes a lesion with a 'stuck on' appearance (without a stalk) e.g. a sessile polyp 

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by a 'target lesion'?

Describes a lesion with concentric rings (like a dartboard)

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'telangiectasia'?

Prominent cutaneous blood vessels

UPDATED 2020
What is an ulcer?

A full thickness loss of epidermis (or epithelium)

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'umbilicated'?

Describes a lesion with a central pit

NOTES
Examples include molluscum contagiosum and herpes simplex.

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'verrucous'?

Describes a wart-like (thickened and scaly) lesion

UPDATED 2020
What is a vesicle?

A blister, <1cm across

UPDATED 2020
What is a weal?

An oedematous papule or plaque, due to swelling in the dermis

NOTES
Weals are a sign of urticaria.


UPDATED 2020
Where are the eccrine glands found?
Most dense on the palms, soles, armpits, and forehead.
Which nail lesions are seen in psoriasis?

Pitting, salmon patches, onycholysis.

NOTES
Salmon patches = irregular area of yellow or pink discolouration, due to inflammation in the nail bed.
Onycholysis = distal separation of nail plate from nail bed.


Pitting and onycholysis

UPDATED 2020
What are the treatment options for psoriasis?

1. Conservative e.g. patient education.

2. Topical e.g. emollients, corticosteroids, vitamin D analogues, retinoids, tar, phototherapy.

3. Systemic e.g. retinoids, methotrexate, cyclosporin, biologics.

NOTES
Vitamin D analogues e.g. calciptriene, calcitriol.
Topical retinoids e.g. tazarotene.
Biologics e.g. adalimumab (anti TNF) and ustkinumab (anti IL-12/23).
UPDATED 2020
List the types of dermatitis (eczema)

Sort by mechanism

Primarily exogenous
1. Irritant contact-
2. Allergic contant-

Primarily endogenous
1. Atopic-
2. Seborrheic-
3. Discoid (nummular)-
4. Venous (stasis)-
5. Asteatotic-
6. Dyshidrotic eczema (pompholyx)

UPDATED 2020
What is meant by 'eczematous'?

Describes a lesion with erythema, scaling, crusting, and serous oozing.

UPDATED 2020
Where are the sebaceous glands found?

Most dense in the scalp, mid face, chest, and upper back.

UPDATED 2020
What is seborrheic dermatitis?

A common chronic inflammatory skin disorder

NOTES
Lesions: poorly defined areas of erythema and scale on lateral nose, nasolabial folds, eyebrows, glabella, and scalp (seborrheic areas).
Dandruff is a mild form of seborrheic dermatitis.
Malassezia yeasts are believed to play a role in pathogenesis.
Treatment: topical corticosteroids and antifungals.

Dermatitis involving lateral nose, eyebrows and glabella

Dermatitis involving nasolabial folds

UPDATED 2020
What is allergic contact dermatitis?

A type of inflammatory skin disorder

NOTES
Lesions: poorly defined, intensely itchy, papular dermatitis.
Pathogenesis: contact with a particular substance triggers a delayed (type 4) hypersensitivity reaction.
Common triggers include poison ivy, nickel, certain perfumes and cosmetics.

Allergic contact dermatitis

UPDATED 2020
What is irritant contact dermatitis?

A type of inflammatory skin disorder

NOTES
Lesion: areas of erythema, dryness, and fissuring.
Pathogenesis: contact with an irritant substance causes dermatitis.
Common triggers include daily exposure to soapy water or alcohol gel.
Napkin rash in infants is a form of irritant contact dermatitis.

Irritant contact dermatitis

UPDATED 2020
What is dyshidrotic eczema (pompholyx)?

An uncommon chronic inflammatory skin disorder

NOTES
Lesions: intensely itchy, chronic and recurrent vesicular dermatitis of palms, soles, and lateral aspects of the fingers.
Aetiology is not well understood.
Treatment: medium to potent corticosteroids for flares.


UPDATED 2020
What is discoid eczema?

A chronic inflammatory skin disorder

NOTES
Lesions: intensely itchy circular patches of dermatitis on the trunk and lower extremities (the head is spared).
Aetiology is not well understood.
Treatment: potent topical corticosteroid for flares.

Discoid eczema

UPDATED 2020
What is atopic eczema?

A chronic inflammatory skin disease that occurs most often in children.




UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of infantile atopic eczema?

History
Typically presents after the first 2 months of life.
Itchy rash.

Exam
Inspection: red, scaly, crusted lesions on cheeks, scalp, trunk and extensor surfaces. Usually sparing of the nappy area.

NOTES

Intantile eczema

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of childhood atopic ezcema?

History
Chronic itchy rash.

Exam
Inspection: lichenified plaques in a flexural distribution, especially the antecubital and popliteal fossae, volar aspect of wrists, ankles, and neck.

NOTES

Childood eczema

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of adult atopic eczema?

History
Chronic itchy rash.

Exam
Inspection: markedly lichenified plaques in flexural areas e.g. neck, antecubital and popliteal fossae.

NOTES

Adult atopic eczema

UPDATED 2020
What are the complications of atopic eczema?

Sort by mechanism

1. Impetigo (Staphylococcus aureus).
2. Eczema herpeticum (HSV).
3. Tinea (dermatophyte).
4. Psychological e.g. low mood.

NOTES
HSV = herpes simplex virus.

Impetigo

Eczema herpeticum

UPDATED 2020
What are the treatment options for atopic eczema?

1. Conservative e.g. maintain skin hydration.

2. Topical meds: corticosteroids (first line); calcineurin inhibitors (second line).

3. Systemic meds e.g. oral corticosteroids (consider short course).

NOTES
Corticosteroid choice depends on the patient's age, body area involved, and severity of inflammation.
Typical treatment for a mild flare is low potency steroid applied twice daily for 2-4 weeks, together with generous emollients.

UPDATED 2020
What is pityriasis rosea?

An acute, self-limited viral rash, characterised by oval inflammatory lesions on the trunk and proximal extremities.

NOTES

Aetiology suspected to be viral.
Treatment is symptomatic relief for pruritus.

Updated 2020
What are the clinical features of pityriasis rosea?

History
Typical patient is a young adult.
'Herald patch' on the chest, neck, or back.
Several days later, itchy oval lesions (similar to herald patch but smaller) appear on trunk or proximal limbs.

Exam
Inspection: oval, sharply defined, pink lesions on the torso and proximal limbs.

NOTES
Herald patch: 2-5cm pink lesion, soon becomes scaly and begins to clear centrally, resulting in a 'colarette' of scale.
Disease course: usually resolves within 2-3 months.

Pityriasis rosea


 UPDATED 2020
Which unit is used to measure the dose of topical corticosteroid?

The fingertip unit (FTU)

UPDATED 2020
When using topical corticosteroids and emollients, which should be applied first?

Emollients.

NOTES
Apply emollient first, then wait 15 mins before applying the corticosteroid. The skin should be moist but not slippery.

UPDATED 2020
Name a 'mild' topical corticosteroid

Hydrocortisone 0.1-2.5%

UPDATED 2020
Name a 'moderate' topical corticosteroid

Eumovate - Clobetasone butyrate

UPDATED 2020
Name a 'potent' topical corticosteroid

Betnovate - Betamethasone valerate

UPDATED 2020
Name a 'very potent' topical corticosteroid

Dermovate - Clobetasol propionate

UPDATED 2020
Describe the pathogenesis of acne

Sort chronologically

1. Pilosebaceous follicle hyperkeratinisation.
2. Increased sebum production.
3. Propionibacterium acnes proliferation within follicle.
4. Inflammation.

UPDATED 2020
Which skin lesions are seen in acne?

Sort by type

1. Closed comedones (whiteheads).
2. Open comedones (blackheads).
3. Inflammatory papules.
4. Scarring.
5. Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of acne?

History
Typical patient is a teenager.
Papular rash in sebaceous distribution.

Exam
Inspection: comedones, inflammatory papules, may be scars and hyperpigmentation in sebacous distribution.

NOTES
Sebaceous areas = mid face, neck, chest, upper back.

UPDATED 2020
What is acne fulminans?

Severe acne conglobata with fever and arthralgias



UPDATED 2020
What is acne conglobata?

A severe form of nodularcystic acne

NOTES
Typical patient is a teenage male.
Lesions: inflammatory nodules with sinus tracts and severe scarring.
Treatment: oral antibiotics, corticosteroids, isotretinoin, and surgical intervention.


UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of secondary acne?

Sort by mechanism

1. Hyperandrogenism e.g. PCOS, Cushing syndrome.
2. Meds e.g. corticosteroids, phenytoin, lithium, isoniazid.

NOTES
PCOS = polycystic ovary syndrome.
 
UPDATED 2020
What is acne rosacea?

A common acneiform skin disorder with involvement of the central face

NOTES
Subtypes: erythemato-telangiectatic, papulopustular, phymatous, and ocular.
Erythematotelagiectatic = persistent erythema, facial flushing, telangiectasias, roughness and scaling.
Papulopustular = papules and pustules in the central face (no comedones).
Phymatous = thickened skin with irregular contours.

Telangiectasia

Papulopustular rosacea

Advanced rhinophyma

 UPDATED 2020
What is perioral (periorificial) dermatitis?

An acneiform disorder.

NOTES
Aetiology is unclear, potent topical corticosteroids may trigger or exacerbate.
Lesions: multiple 1-2mm clustered erythematous papules in a perioral distribution.

Perioral dermatitis.

UPDATED 2020
What are the treatment options for acne?

1. Conservative e.g. patient education

2. Topical e.g. retinoids, benzoyl peroxide, antibiotics.

3. Systemic e.g. antibiotics, isotretinoin, hormonal therapies.

UPDATED 2020
What is the mechanism of action of benzoyl peroxide?

Antimicrobial.

UPDATED 2020
What is the mechanism of action of isotretinoin?

Reduction in sebum production and hyperkeratinisation

UPDATED 2020
What are the adverse effects of isotretinoin?

Sort by mechanism

1. Teratogenicity e.g. spontaneous abortion and life-threatening malformations (Female patients must use two forms of contraception wilst taking) 
2. Dry skin and mucous membranes e.g. cheilitis (inflammation of the lips) 

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of urticaria?

History
Transient itchy rash, often worse at night.

Exam
Inspection: circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques, with variable shape and size.

NOTES

Urticaria

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of urticaria?

Sort by mechanism

1. Infection e.g. viral, bacterial.
2. IgE allergic reaction e.g. meds, food, insect sting.
3. Direct mast cell activation e.g. opiates, muscle relaxants, stinging nettle.
4. NSAIDs (pseudoallergy).

UPDATED 2020
What are the treatment options for urticaria?

1. Conservative e.g. patient education.

2. Meds
Antihistamines e.g. loratidine, chlorphenamine.
Corticosteroids e.g. short course prednisolone.

UPDATED 2020
What is onycholysis?

Distal separation of nail plate from nail bed.




NOTES
Seen in trauma, wet work, psoriasis, lichen planus, etc.

UPDATED 2020
What is digital clubbing?

Increased distal finger tip mass with increased nail plate curvature.

NOTES
The Lovibond angle is >180° in clubbed nails (160° in non-clubbed nails).

Digital clubbing

 UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of acquired bilateral digital clubbing?

Sort by organ system

1. Pulmonary e.g. lung cancer, fibrosis, TB.
2. Cardiac e.g. cyanotic heart disease, subacute endocarditis.
3. Extrathoracic e.g. IBD, cirrhosis, GIT neoplasms.

UPDATED 2020
What are half-and-half nails?

A sign of chronic renal insufficiency and uraemia

NOTES
Lesion: white proximal half, brown distal half.
Nails may revert to normal following renal transplantation.

Half-and-half nails
 UPDATED 2020
What is koilonychia?

'Spoon shaped' nails, a sign of iron deficiency

NOTES

Koilonychia

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of a purpuric rash?

Sort by platelet count

1. Low platelets
Decreased production e.g. bone marrow failure.
Increased destruction e.g. ITP, DIC, TTP/HUS.

2. Normal platelets
Infection e.g. meningococcus, measles, dengue fever.
Inflammatory e.g. vasculitis, HSP.
Drugs e.g. corticosteroids.

UPDATED 2020
What is erythema nodosum?

Painful erythematous subcutaneous nodules, usually on the shins.

NOTES
Pathogenesis is unclear.
Seen after Strep pharyngitis, and in sarcoidosis, inflammatory bowel disease, and Behçet disease.

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of erythema nodosum?

Sort by incidence

Most common
1. Streptococcal pharyngitis.
2. Idiopathic.

All the rest
1. Sarcoidosis.
2. Tuberculosis.
3. IBD.
4. Pregnancy and OCP.



UPDATED 2020
What is pyoderma gangrenosum?

A type of inflammatory ulcer, usually on legs or trunk

NOTES
Majority of cases are associated with systemic disease.
Clinically: an inflammatory papule progresses to a painful ulcer with a purple border and a purulent base.

 
Pyoderma gangrenosum

UPDATED 2020
What are the causes of pyoderma gangrenosum?

Sort by incidence

1. IBD.
2. Haematological cancer.
3. Inflammatory arthritis e.g. RA, ankylosing spondylitis.




UPDATED 2020
List the clinical variants of malignant melanoma

Sort by incidence

1. Superficial spreading.
2. Nodular.
3. Lentigo maligna.
4. Acral lentiginous.

NOTES

Superficial spreading

Nodular

Lentigo maligna

Acral lentiginous

 UPDATED 2020
Which checklist is used as a diagnostic aid in suspected malignant melanoma?

ABCDE checklist

NOTES
Consider referral if the lesion meets any of the criteria on the the checklist.
A = asymmetry.
B = border irregularities.
C = colour variegation.
D = diameter ≥6mm.
E = evolving.

UPDATED 2020
Which are the most important prognostic factors in malignant melanoma?

Sort by order of importance

1. Tumour thickness.
2. Mitotic rate.
3. Ulceration.

UPDATED 2020
What are the risk factors for malignant melanoma?

Sort by history

Demographics e.g. age, light skin phenotype.
PMHx e.g. previous skin cancer, high number of common naevi, atypical naevi.
SHx e.g. high sun exposure, history of sun burns.

UPDATED 2020
What are the treatment options for malignant melanoma?

Sort by members of the MDT

1. Surgeon e.g. WLE, lymphadenectomy, excision of mets.
2. Nurse specialist e.g. patient education.
3. Oncologist e.g. chemotherapy, radiotherapy (limited role).
4. Palliative care.

UPDATED 2020
What are the clinical features of malignant melanoma?

History

How is the ovarian cycle divided?
Follicular phase -> Ovulation -> Luteal Phase
What happens in the follicular phase of the ovarian cycle?

Through the rise of FSH in the first few days of the cycle a few ovarian follicles are stimulated.

These follicles compete for dominance.

Under the influence of several hormones all but one of these follicles will stop growing while the one dominant follicle will continue to maturity.

The follicle that reaches maturity is called a tertiary or Graffian follicle and it contains the ovum.
What happens in the ovulation phase of the ovarian cycle?

A mature egg is released from the ovarian follicles into the oviduct.

When the egg is nealy matured levels of oestradiol reach a level which causes an LH surge which starts around day 12.

The release of LH matures the egg and weakens the wall of the follicle in the ovary, causing the fully developed follicle to release its secondary oocyte.

After being released the egg is swept into the gallopian tube by the fimbria. 

If fertilised the egg immediately begins embryogenesis. 

The developing embryo takes about three days to reach the uterus and another three days to implant into the endometrium.
Where does fetilisation of an egg usually occur?
The ampulla of the fallopian tubes
In some women ovulation features a characteristic pain called {{c1::mittelschmerz}}.
The sudden change in hormones at the time of ovulation sometimes causes {{c1::light mid-cycle blood flow}}.
What happens in the luteal phase of the ovarian cycle?

The pituitary hormones FSH and LH cause the remaining parts of the dominant follicle to transform into the corpus luteum which produces progesterone.

The increased progesterone in the adrenals starts to induce the production of oestrogen.

The hormones produced by the corpus luteum also suppress LH and FSH which the corpus luteum needs to sustain itself so the corpus luteum atrophies.

Falling levels of progesterone trigger menstrution.


The loss of the corpus luteum is prevented by fertilisation. The syncytiotrophoblast produces hCG which is similiar to LH and preserves the corpus luteum. The corpus luteum then can continue to maintain the new pregnancy.  Most pregnancy tests look for this.
What do pregnancy tests look for?
The presence of hCG (human chorionic gonadotrophin).
What are the three phases of the uterine cycle?
Menses -> Proliferative -> Secretory
What happens in proliferation in the uterine cycle?

Oestrogen causes the lining of the uterus to grow. 

As they mature the ovarian follicles secrete increasing amounts of oestradiol and oestrogen. 

The oestrogens initiate the formation of a new layer of endometrium in the uterus.

The oestrogen also stimulates crypts in the cervix to produce cervical mucus which causes vaginal discharge regardless of arousal.
What happens in the secretory phase of the uterine cycle?

Corresponds to the luteal phase of the ovarian cycle.

The progesterone produced by the corpus luteum makes the endometrium receptive to implantation of the blastocyst and supportive of early pregnancy, by increasing blood flow and uterine secretions and reducing the contractility of the smooth muscle in the uterus. 

The progesterone also increases the women's basal body temperature.
Recall the diagram of the various hormone in the menstrual cycle.

When is AAA screening offered?

Offered to men during the year they turn 65.

Older men can self-refer.
When is bowel cancer screening offered?

FIT offered to men and women aged 60 to 74 every 2 years. 
Those over 75 can request screening.

In some areas people aged 55 are invited for a one-off bowel scope screening test.
When is breast cancer screening offered?
Offered every 3 years to women aged from 50 up to their 71st birthday.
When is cervical screnning offered?
Offered to women aged from 25 to 49 every 3 years and women aged from 50 to 64 every 5 years.
When is diabetic eye screening offered?
Offered annually to people with diabetes aged 12 and over.
What screening is given to newborns?

-Newborn hearing screen.
-Physical examination within 3 days of birth and again at 6-8 weeks.
-Newborn blood spot for 9 rare conditions.
What screening is offered in pregnancy?

-Sickle cell and thalassaemia (ideally by 10 weeks)
-Infectious diseases (HIV, hep B and syphilis)
-Down's, Edward's and Patau's
-11 Physical conditions in the baby (20 week scan)
-Diabetic retinopathy (for women with diabetes)
What are the pros and cons of the PSA screening test?

Pros:
-Can pick up cancer before any symptoms
-May pick up a fast growing cancer and treatment could stop the spread
-Having regular tests could be helpful for men at risk as changes could be investigated
Cons:
-Many men with a raised psa don't have prostate cancer
-The test may miss cancer. 1 in 7 with a normal PSA have prostate cancer and 1 in 50 men have a fast growing cancer with a normal PSA.
-If your PSA is raised you may need a biopsy. This can cause side effects of: pain, infection and blood in the urine and semen.
-You may be diagnosed with a slow growing cancer which is not harmful but now you may worry about it.
-Treatments for prostate cancer have side affects that can affect your daily life including bowel, urinary and erectile problems.

How is asthma diagnosed?

In children < 5 with suspected asthma treat on observation and clinical judgement

In children between 5 and 16:
Symptoms suggestive of asthma
AND 
FeNO ≥ 35 ppb and positive peak flow variablilty
OR
Obstructive spirometry and positive bronchodilator reversibility

In adults aged 17 or over:
Symptoms suggestive of asthma
AND
FeNO ≥ 40 ppb and positive peak flow variablilty or positive bronchodilator reversibility or bronchial hyperreactivity
OR
FeNO between 25 and 39 ppb and a postive bronchial challenge test
OR
Positive bronchodilator reversibility and positive peak flow variability irrespective of FeNO level.

[NICE 2020]
How is heart failure diagnosed?

-Take a history and clinical exam
-Measure NT-proBNP 
-If >2000 ng/litre refer urgently for assessment and transthoracic echo within 2 weeks.
-If between 400 and 2000 ng/litre refer for assessment and transthoracic echo within 6 weeks.
-Perform an ECG and look for alternatives (e.g. chest xray, blood tests urinanalysis)

How does appendicitis usually present?

What is the pathophysiology of appendicitis?

Acute appendicitis seems to be the result of a primary obstruction of the appendix.
Once this occurs the appendix becomes filled with mucus and swells.
The increased pressure results in thrombosis and occlusion of the small vessels.
As the occlusion continues the appendix becomes ischemic and then necrotic.
As bacteria begin to leak through the dying walls pus forms within and around the appendix.
The end result is a burst appendix causing peritonitis which may lead to sepsis and eventually death.

Then once clear start a maintenance laxative treatment of a macrogol for several weeks of regular bowel habits

What is the pathophysiology of bronchiolitis in children?

Although the exact mechanism is unclear, it is likely that direct viral cytotoxic injury has a role in the pathogenesis of RSV infections. This leads to necrosis of the epithelial cells of the small airways, and the sloughed cells and mucus cause plugging of the bronchioles that leads to hyperinflation and atelectasis.

What is the specific CV risk advise for Diet?

Advise the person to adopt a diet that helps reduve CVD risk
Eating 
-Unsatled nuts, seeds and legumes - at least 4-5 portions a errk
-Fish - at least two portions a week
-Fruit and vegetables - at least 5 portions a day
-Fibre - eat 30-45g per day
Reduce
-Sugar and foods containing refined sugars, including fructose
-Saturated fat - total fat intake should be 30% or less of total energy intake and saturated fat 7% or less
-Salt - should be <6g per day. Avoid adding salt at the table and keep processed foods to a minimum
Increase
-Mono-unsaturated fat intake with olive oil or rapeseed oil in spreads and use these oils in food prep
-Dietary supplements including omega-3 capsules, plant sterols ARE NOT recommeded as there is no good evidence they reduce CVD risk
What is the specific CV risk advise for activity?

-At least 150 minutes per week of moderate intensity aerobic activity (to the point of slight breathlessness) OR at least 75 minutes per week of vigarous intensity aerobic activty 
-And muscle strengthening activites on two or more days a week that work all major groups
-Encourage people who cannot manage this to exercise to their maximum safe capacity
What is the specific CV risk advise for alcohol consumption?

-For men and women: no more than 14 units per week spread over 3 days or more
-Avoid binge drinking and intoxication
-If alcohol use seems to be a problem it should specifically be addressed

What is the MOA of the combined pill?

-Oestrogen inhibits secretion of FSH via negative feedback on the anterior pituitary and thus suppresses development of the ovarian follicle
-Progesterone inhibits secretion of LH and thus prevents ovulation, it also  makes the cervical mucus less suitable for the passage of sperm
-Oestrogen and progesterone act in concert to alter the endometrium in such a way as to discourage implantation
What is the MOA of the progesterone only pill?

-Primarily the cervical mucus is made inhospitable to sperm
The progesterone also probably hinders implantation through its effect on the endometrium and on the motitility and secretions of the fallopian tubes

- Ensure the position of the placenta

20 week scan (Between 18 to 21 weeks)
- Screens for 11 rare conditions including: Anencephaly, Spina bifida, Cleft lip, Diaphgramatic hernia, Gastroschisis, Exophalos, Cardiac abnormalities, Bilateral renal agenesis, Skeletal dysplasia, Edwards syndrome (T18) and Patau's syndrome (T13)

Vitamin D supplement is recommended

What is pre-eclampsia?

A disorder of pregnancy associated with new-onset hypertension (defined as a blood pressure ?140 mmHg systolic and/or ?90 mmHg diastolic), which occurs most often after 20 weeks of gestation and frequently near term. Although often accompanied by new-onset proteinuria, hypertension and other signs or symptoms of pre-eclampsia may present in some women in the absence of proteinuria.
How is pre-eclampsia treated?

1st line
- Admitted into hospital for monitoring
- Decision regarding delivery. (<34 weeks continuing pregnancy is advisable with monitoring, 34-36 weeks decision made on a case by case basis, 37 weeks and over immediate delivery)
- Antihypertensive therapy
- Magnesium sulphate if seizures present

When should continous cardiotocography be used during labour?

Should be used if any of the following risk factors arise during initial assessment or during labour:
- Maternal pulse over 120bpm on 2 occaisons 30 minutes apart
- Temp 38°C or above on a single reading OR 37.5°C or above on 2 consecutive occaisons 1 hour apart
- Suspected chorioamnionitis or sepsis
- Pain reported by the woman that differs from the pain normally associated with contractions
What is a normal baseline foetal heart rate?
What are non-reassuring or abnormal foetal heart rates?

Non-reassuring
- 100-109bpm
- 161-180bpm

ABNORMAL
- below 100bpm
- above 180bpm

5-25 bpm

Non-reassuring
- less than 5bpm for 30 to 50 minutes
- more than 25bpm for 15-25 minutes

ABNORMAL
- less than 5bpm for more than 50 minutes
- more than 25bpm for more than 25 minutes
- Sinusoidal
What are concerning characteristics for variable heart rate decelerations?

- Lasting more than 60 seconds
- Reduced baseline variability within the deceleration
- Failure to return to baseline
- Biphasic (W) shape
- No shouldering
What is normal for foetal heart rate decelerations?

- No decelerations
- Early decelerations
- Variable decelerations with no concerning characteristics for less than 90 minutes
What are non-reassuring features of foetal heart rate decelerations?

Non-reassuring
- Variable decelerations with no concerning characteristics for 90 minutes or more
- Variable decelerations with any concerning characteristics in up to 50% of contractions for 30 minutes or more
- Variable decelerations with any concerning characteristics in over 50% of contractions for less than 30 minutes
- Late decelerations in over 50% of contractions for less than 30 minutes, with no maternal or foetal clinical risk factors such as vaginal bleeding or significant meconium

Abnormal
- Variable decelerations with any concerning characteristics in over 50% of contractions for 30 minutes (or less if there are any maternal or foetal clinical risk factors)
- Late decelerations for 30 minutes (or less if there are any maternal or foetal clinical risk factors)
- Acute bradycardia, or a single prolonged deceleration lasting 3 minutes or more
Are foetal heart rate accelerations a positive or negative sign?

Postive sign
- The presence of accelerations, even with reduced baseline variability, is generally a sign that the baby is healthy

What appointments should a prospective mother make to a healthcare professional?

4. 28 weeks appointment

6. 34 weeks appointment

What occurs at the 8-12 week booking appointment?

The midwife or doctor will:
- Give handheld notes and plan of care
- Plan the care you'll get through pregnancy and determine if you may need additional care or support
- Identify any potential risks associated with any work you may do
- Measure height, weight, BMI, BP and test urine for protein.
- Determine risk of pre-eclampsia or gestational diabetes
- Offer screening tests and ensure you understand what is involved
- Offer 2 ultrasound scans (8-14 weeks and 18-20 weeks)
- Ask about mood and identify possible depression
- Ask about any past or present severe mental illness of psychiatric treatment
What occurs at the 16 weeks appointment?

Midwife or doctor will give paitent information on the 18-20 week ultrasound. They will also:-
- Review, discuss and record the results of any screening tests
- Measure the patients blood pressure and test urine for protein
- Consider an iron supplement in anaemic
What occurs at the 25 weeks appointment for a first time mother?

Doctor or midwife will
- Use a tape meaure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Measure the patients BP and test urine for protein
What occurs at the 28 weeks appointment for a mother?

Doctor or midwife will
- Use a tape meaure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Measure the patients BP and test urine for protein
- Offer more screening tests
- Offer the first anti-D treatment if the patient is rhesus negative
- Consider an iron supplement if anaemic
What occurs at the 31 week appointment for a first time mother?

Doctor or midwife will
- Review, discuss and record results of any screening tests from the last appointment
- Use a tape measure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Measure the patients blood pressure and test urine for protein
What occurs at the 34 week appointment for a mother?

Doctor or midwife will give the patient information about preparing for labour and birth, including how to recognise active labour, ways of coping with pain in labour and the patients birth plan. They will also disscuss and give information on a caesarean section:
- Review, discuss and record the results of any screening tests from the last appointment
- Use a tape measure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Measure the patients blood pressure and test urine for protein
- Offer the patient a second anti-D treatment if rhesus negative
What occurs at the 36 week appointment for a mother?

Doctor or midwife will give the patient information about:
- Breastfeeding
- Caring for the newborn
- Vitamin K and screening tests for the newborn
- Mothers health after the baby is born
- Talk about the baby blues and postnatal depression

They will also:
- Use a tape measure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Check the position of the baby
- Measure the mothers blood pressure and test urine for protein
- Offer external cephalic version (ECV) if the baby is in the breech position
What occurs at the 38 week appointment for a mother?

Doctor or midwife will discuss the options and choices about what happens if the patients pregnancy lasts longer than 41 weeks. They will also:
- Use a tape measure to measure the size of the patients uterus
- Measure the patients blood pressure and test urine for protein

- Bypass graft 

Closed
- Endovascular thrombolysis
What is the long term treatment for chronically ischaemic limbs?

Medication
- Anticoagulation 
- Antihypertensives 

Lifestyle
- Stop smoking 
- Increase exercise
Which conditions are included in acute aortic syndrome?

- Aortic dissection
- Intramural thrombus
- Penertrating atherosclerotic aortic ulcer
What are important questions to ask when reviewing a limb fracture?

- How is the patient, any other life-threatening injuries? 
- Are there pulses proximal and distal to the fracture?
- Is the limb pink or pale? 
- What is the capillary refill time? 
- Is it an open or closed injury? 
- Is there any evidence of neurological injury?
What classification system is used to describe supracondylar humerus fractures?
Gartland Classification
How do you examine the limb after a supracondylar humerus fracture?
Rock, Paper, Scissors, OK
What is the primary mechanism of injury for a supracondylar humerus fracture?

Hyperextension 
1. Falls onto outstretched hand
2. Elbow becomes locked in hyperextension 
3. Tension forces anterioly and olecranon is forced into the olecranon fossa
4. Triceps causes posterior and proximal migration of distal fracture fragment
Why are supracondylar fractures more common in 5-7 year olds?
At this age the supracondylar area is remodelling and is thinner than at other ages
Picture how a flexion type supracondylar humerus fracture occurs
Name some classification systems of supracondylar humerus fractures

- Gartland classification 
- Wilkins Modification (uses Gartland classification)
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 1a
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 1b
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 2a
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 3a
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 3a
What Gartland classification is this fracture?
Type 3b
How is Gartland type 1 fractures treated?

- Type 1 fractures usually have intact periosteum and thus inherently stable 
- Simple immbolisation with a posterior splint applied at 60-90 degress of elbow flexion 
- Radiographs 3-7 days post injury to check for displacement 
- Imobilisation for 3-4 weeks
How are Gartland type 2 fractures treated?
- Any type II fracture with unacceptable inital alignment or for which there is concern about displacement or noncompliant follow-up should be reduced and pinned
Describe the pattern of upper limb growth during the first 5 years of life?

1st year - 10cm 
2nd year - 6cm
3rd year - 5cm
4th year - 3.5cm
5th year - 3cm
How do you treat a type III Gartland classification fracture?

Prior to theatre place arm in temporary cast of 30 degrees of flexion 
- Acute manipulative reduction 
- Traction
What is the most common type of neurological injury in supracondylar fracture?
- Transient neuropraxia
What is the most commonly injuried nerve in a supracondylar humerus fracture?
Median nerve
How long will it generally take for a nerve injury to recover after the inital injury?
- 2-2.5 months but may take up to 6 months
Even though nerve transections are rare, which is most commonly transected in a supracondylar humerus fracture?
- Radial nerve
Name the major ligaments of the knee joint

- Anterior cruciate ligament (ACL)

- Lateral collateral ligament (LCL) 
- Medial collateral ligament (MCL)
What are the 3 layers of the medial supporting structures of the knee?

Superficial layer 
- Crural fascia - fascia continuous with fascia covering vastus medialis and posteriorly covering sartorious muscle 

Middle layer 
Superficial MCL 
- Anterior vertical portion - separated from the deep MCL by fat and MCL bursa 
- Posterior oblique portion - blends with medial meniscus - called posterior oblique ligament 

Deep layer 
- Deep MCL - Medial capsular ligament
